moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nf6 3. d3 Bc5 4. Nf3 Nc6: Fairly standard openings here, board is mirrored.
moves.6. Bg5 h6 7. Bh4 Bg4 8. Nd5 g5 9. Bg3 Nx: Trading pieces trying to establish position.
moves.12. gxf3 Be6 13. Bxb7 Rb8 14. Bc6+ Bd7 1: Attacks beginning to form on the g and h ranks.
Attacking the a1 Rook and setting up an attack on white's King.
moves.22. Rb1: Blunder, Rc1 has the Rook defended by the Bishop on f4 but is also a blunder, best move with this Rook would be Rd1 to guard against ... Qc3+ with Bd2.
moves.22... Qc3+ 23. Kf1: Because he did not play Rd1, Bd2 would just force mate in two with ... Qxd2+ Kf1 Qxf2#.
moves.23... Qxd3+ 24. Kg2: Kg1 a better move here, even though mate has been forced since Rb1.  Instead, mate is now in 5 rather than around 8.  I used this position for chess puzzle #47830.
moves.24... Rxf2+: The key move here in this mate, with the Rook being protected by the c5 Bishop.
moves.25. Kh1: Kg1 would still result in mate with ... Qxb1+ Bc1 Qxc1+ Qd1 Qxd1#.
moves.25... Qxb1+: Potentially I could have played ... Qxe4+ here as well, either resulting in Qg2 Qxg2# or Qf3 Qxf3+ Kg1 Qg2#, or if Kg1 then ... Qxb1+ Bc1 Qxc1+ Qd1 Qxd1#.
moves.26. Qg1: White could've lengthened the game with Bc1 before this move, preventing ... Qxe4+, but instead would've resulted in ... Qxh6+ Qh2, then either Rxh2# or Qxh2#.
moves.26... Qxe4+: Now his only move is Qg2.
